headline: Engineering & Technology Thought Leader | Empowering the Next Generation of Digital Leaders | ex Fintech | ex IBM
about:
As a devoted father to an amazing daughter, I am constantly reminded of the importance of setting a strong example of dedication, compassion, and excellence in everything I do, and this drives me to strive for nothing less than greatness as a global technology thought leader.

With a career spanning of three decades, I have been fortunate to spearhead some of the most transformative changes in the tech world by leading and scaling global engineering teams and delivering robust systems and products across highly regulated industries. 

At the core of my leadership philosophy lies a people-first approach, and my unwavering commitment to empowering and enabling those around me. I take great satisfaction in mentoring and coaching the next generation of digital leaders by challenging legacy thinking and instilling in them the values of collaboration, innovation, and continuous learning. 

Currently, I'm serving as the Director of Engineering at Google, where leading an hybrid workforce enablement and strategic initiative that leverages the power of cloud to enhance developer  productivity, agility, and efficiency across the company by providing compute on the cloud that is elastic, highly available and secure.

It is an exciting time to be facing the challenges of the future, and further exploring how we, as industry leaders, can continue to add impactful and measurable value and change for the customers, businesses and the communities we serve and represent.


Key Competencies: Engineering | Cloud Computing | Infrastructure and Operations | DevOps | Technical Leadership | People Development | Strategic Planning | Change Management | Agile Methodologies | Project Management | SRE

headline: VP, Human Resources at Epredia (a KKR Portfolio Company) / Member of Chief
about:
Juanita Hendrickson serves as the HR leader for Epredia, (a KKR Portfolio Company). During her 22+ year career, Ms. Hendrickson has held senior leadership roles in the world’s best-known Fortune 300 organizations, including Thermo Fisher Scientific (NYSE: TMO), Baxter (NYSE: BAX), Waste Management  (NYSE: WM), and the German company Merck (MRK.DE). Ms. Hendrickson’s experience includes successful integrations of large and complex acquisitions, including one of the most significant acquisitions, Merck’s $17B acquisition of Sigma-Aldrich in 2015.  

An accomplished public speaker, Ms. Hendrickson is frequently sought to share her expertise on matters related to diversity & inclusion, leadership, talent, culture, and employee engagement. 

Prior to joining Epredia, Ms. Hendrickson led global teams in both business and Human Resource functions, including Corporate Development, Human Resources, and Operations Management. Ms. Hendrickson’s breadth of experience bridges from start-up to mature organizations, pre and post Initial Public Offerings (IPO), and spans a variety of sectors, including the life science, environmental, and software industries.

In addition to writing prose, I hold a certificate in screenwriting from The New School. 

I bring a commitment to community, equity, social justice, storytelling artistry, and creativity to each of my projects and teams.

headline: Go To Market Strategy at Google
CNN Hero | CEO & Founder TechLit Africa | Forbes 30 Under 30 | We leverage the digital economy to lift communities out of poverty | Keynote Speaker
about:
I grew up in a rural village in Kenya. The situation there was dire. Circumstances forced me to raise my younger sister when I was just nine years old. I wanted to change the narrative of kids growing up in communities like mine. I want to fix poverty, and for good this time.

Through hard work and determination, I landed a full scholarship to Augustana College, in America. Coming to the United States and studying computer science gave me the platform to accelerate my impact. As an undergrad, I invested all of my income from various campus jobs into my community back in Kenya. I built a school, Zawadi, there and later started TechLit Africa.

TechLit Africa is a non-profit American organization that redistributes recycled technology to build computer labs in African schools. We have already built 10 computers in rural Kenya and are currently working on our next 100 computer labs. We already have around 4,000 students and 20 teachers. By next year we will have around 40,000 students and 200 teachers.

Our program is unique because we teach classes that are relevant; we hire local teachers to make sure of it. We train our own teachers to run the computer labs in their own community, who meet every day to improve their classes. We are unlocking a world of opportunities to these kids. They will be inspired to take on a dozen careers: they will have the skills to tap into the global economy straight from the village.

This is my life's work because I know first hand how awful poverty is. We plan to do this for the whole of rural Africa, positioning ourselves to 10x our growth year after year. TechLit is my opportunity to fix poverty, and for good this time.

education.major: Bachelor of Arts Computer Science and Applied Mathematics, Computer Science

Lynch is also a regular contributor on HR and workforce trends for Forbes as well as an industry commentator on diversity, online safety for kids, the cyber security skills shortage and more.

headline: Director at Google
about:
Guy Lebanon is a director at Google where he works on ensuring the security, privacy, trust, and safety of mobile apps on Android, the world's most popular operating system. Previously, he led search quality at Amazon as a director of engineering, and earlier he was a director at Netflix and a tenured professor at the Georgia Institute of Technology. Guy published several books and over 70 refereed articles and received a PhD in machine learning from Carnegie Mellon University. He chaired the 2015 AI & Statistics conference and the 2012 ACM CIKM conference and was action editor of the Journal of Machine Learning Research during 2013-2018. He won first place in the PASCAL image segmentation competition three times, and received an NSF CAREER Award, the WWW best student paper award, the ICML best paper runner-up award, the Yahoo Faculty Research and Engagement Award, and is a Siebel Scholar.

headline: Vice President of Engineering at Microsoft
about:
Selim Bilgin is an accomplished and highly respected Si Development Leader with more than 22 years of experience developing Flagship Client and Mobile CPUs and SOCs at Intel. He is currently a Vice President and General Manager of Intel’s Validation Engineering Organization leading a team of 2000+ Engineers with Global footprint. Selim brings extensive technical background in SOC, Silicon and Platform development that spans from Silicon Design (Front and Back-End) to SOC Integration, Product Validation and Manufacturing.

During his tenure at Intel, Selim has led the development of multiple game-changing products and technologies which played a pivotal role in maintaining Intel’s Leadership in Processor Design. Some of this key achievements include:

•	Leading the team that developed Intel’s first Uncore, incorporating new technologies, such as Inter-Core-Communication fabric, Memory Controller, DDR, PCIe and QPI, for the first time on an Intel CPU.  He also established new development models, tools, flow and methodologies around this new concept, and skilled the team on these items.
•	Leading the development of a new breed of highly integrated and Power-Efficient SOCs which powered the Ultrabook and 2-in-1 revolution in the industry.
•	Introducing a Silicon development methodology to scale across a portfolio of products with active risk management across the IP suppliers.  

Selim holds 9 patents in the areas of Chip-To-Chip Interconnect Protocols and other Uncore Technologies.

headline: Principal Manager @ Microsoft Healthcare | Agile Project Management, Azure DevOps
about:
I am a Principal Manager of Software Engineering at Microsoft, with over 20 years of experience in developing and delivering cloud-based speech recognition solutions for the healthcare industry. I am a Certified Scrum Master and a Certified Product Owner, with expertise in Azure DevOps, Agile methodologies, and data analysis. 

My mission is to establish a customer-centric software development lifecycle that aligns scrum teams with healthcare providers, develops automated tests based on real-world use cases, and connects previously siloed teams in value streams. I drive innovation by extending our cloud speech platform to support form filling, dictation macros, and multimedia content, enabling PowerScribe One to become a $150M radiology reporting solution used by top medical schools. I also apply LLM-based AI to automate providers' admin tasks at each stage of the patient journey, reducing their administrative burden and burnout. 

I build dynamic teams fueled by ownership, trust, and quality. I use systems thinking and data-driven inspection and adaptation to achieve measurable outcomes. I minimize waste and nurture a culture of continuous experimentation and learning. I deliver on today's commitments while unlocking new organizational capabilities and product offerings through innovation sprints, hackathons, and Ecocyle reviews. I am adept at executing turnaround strategies, leading business transformations, and elevating digital innovation to achieve sustainable increases in agility, profitability, and growth.

I'm an entrepreneur and an engineer. I have worked in Consumer, Enterprise and Web Services, Search and Information Retrieval areas. I currently work at Google as a VP/GM in Google Cloud. Prior to Cloud, I have led engineering and product for Google Maps.

Prior to Google, I was a Founder, CTO and VP of Product Development of The Dealmap; in 2011 The Dealmap was acquired by Google. Prior to that, I worked as a Software Development Lead for Microsoft Local Search and Mapping product: Virtual Earth now known as Bing Maps.

I have filed (and awarded) numerous patents in the web and mapping technology areas. I'm also a published author of a couple of technical books.

Expertise: Software Development, Consumer and Enterprise Software, Web Services, Web Search, Web Platforms, Scalable Distributed Systems, Machine Learning, AI, Natural Language Processing (NLP), Data Mining, Location and Mapping, Product & Technology Leadership, Building Strong and Scalable Teams, Strategic Thinking,  and Hands-on Execution.

headline: Taking a break to play dad and swim
about:
I'm in the midst of taking a career break, primarily focused on hanging out with our elementary school kiddos + training hard for some marathon swims (20+ miles) in summer 2023.

For 12+ years from March 2020 to September 2022, I loved working at LinkedIn because I've always been inspired by its vision: to create economic opportunity for every member of the global workforce. I enjoyed partnering with my colleagues, our customers, and what eventually became 900M+ members to help make this vision a reality. Along the way, we grew LinkedIn >100X from a pre-IPO, ~$100M revenue company to north of $10B, all while building global leadership positions in recruiting, marketing, sales, and learning on top of the world's largest professional network. 

In the past, I grew up in London and then fell in love with Silicon Valley & the Bay Area starting at Stanford in 1995. I spent time in sports business (2000-04) and management consulting at Bain (2004-10) before joining LinkedIn in roles across sales & go-to-market strategy, analytics & insights, marketing, and product management. I know enough to be dangerous across a variety of functions and roles, a generalist who really likes business more broadly vs. a specialist in any particular area.  

At work, I'm impatient to make an impact and have a Nike-inspired JFDI screensaver because Nike has been my favourite company since I was 10-years-old and to remind me that actions often speak louder than words.

Outside of work, I'm a long-term elite endurance athlete (college rowing, Ironman triathlon, bike racing, marathon running, currently marathon swimming), happy husband, doting dad, (Taylor) Swiftie, and compulsive reader and film-goer (here's a public spreadsheet with ALL my books & films ever consumed: bit.ly/z2D1sX)

I sporadically publish a "What's the So What?" newsletter distilling favourite books and experiences into what matters most: https://bit.ly/3q188jL

headline: Corporate Vice President at Microsoft
about:
Yousef Khalidi is CVP of Azure for Operators at Microsoft. Responsible for strategy, partnerships, and technology to bring the power of Azure to the telecommunications industry. He drives engineering investments and strategic business planning including world-wide partnerships and deep integration with Microsoft services.  Yousef was a member of the team that conceived and built the initial version of Microsoft Azure (code named Red Dog), and has served in several engineering, product management, operational, and architectural roles in Azure.

Prior to joining Microsoft, Khalidi spent 14 years at Sun Microsystems where he was a Distinguished Engineer. At Sun, he held several R&D, architecture, and management positions in enterprise software, including CTO and Chief Architect of Solaris, Chief Architect of Sun's N1 utility computing platform, Chief Architect and Director of the Sun Cluster product line, and as a principal architect of the Solaris MC and the Spring advanced development projects. Khalidi also served as a member of Sun’s Technical Advisory Council.

Yousef earned his bachelor's degree in Computer Science from West Virginia University where he graduated summa cum laude. He earned his MS and PhD in Information and Computer Science from Georgia Institute of Technology (Georgia Tech), with a minor in Performance Evaluation & Statistics.

Yousef is a member of Georgia Tech President’s Advisory Board, QCRI’s Scientific Advisory Committee, WVU Lane Department of CSEE Academy of Distinguished Alumni, and Georgia Tech College of Computing Hall of Fame. He previously served on Georgia Tech College of Computing Advisory Board. He holds over 50 patents in distributed systems, networking, object-oriented system, and computer hardware.

location: Jersey City, New Jersey, United States
about:
WHO I AM
Hi, I'm Craig! I've had a love for technology ever since I was a kid and have grown passionate about building things that empower people from building my own quadcopter to take photos to delivering developer tools that help developers drive technology innovation.

WHAT I DO
As a program manager at Microsoft, I own the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) developer tool used by 3M+ developers and IT professionals. I define the product vision and feature prioritization roadmap based on customer data, technical feedback, and market studies. See her Forbes.com articles here: https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadvari/2020/04/23/can-a-sommelier-focused-website-help-you-learn-wine/#6e40ac491cd3


She is in the P32 OIV_MSc wine management program.

A specialist in wine travel, education, journalism, and judging, D'Vari has dozens of high echelon credentials from The Court of Master Sommerliers, Society of Wine Educators, and the American Sommelier Association. 

A long time wine journalist for publications like London's Financial Times and the San Francisco Chronicle, she began her career as an entertainment industry executive at TriStar, where she worked with screenwriters to develop their stories and wrote two books on the screenwriting craft.

How the switch from film to wine?

D'Vari found herself in Boston (spouse career change) and immediately began producing and hosting an interview-format television show to focus on the city's new culinary scene. Among her first guests was Julia Child, and through Julia, Robert Mondavi.

"After the interview with Rorbert Mondavi, I decided to focus more exclusively on the wine world," D'Vari says, admitting that she spends more than half the year visiting wine regions al over Europe.

 D'Vari is now focused on sharing the colorful stories behind winemakers and others in the wine trade in her A Wine Story podcast.

headline: Financial Transformation Executive with a passion for Brand building
about:
An accomplished Executive with success in a wide range of disciplines resulting in her core strength of transitioning strategies into operational execution and efficiency. Neely has a skill set built on experience with a proven track record of achieving desired results through strong analytical, personal engagement, & facilitation skills.

Neely’s career began in public accounting at Grant Thornton, LLP where she participated in an International Secondment to Sydney, Australia & was quickly promoted to Manager. Next, she transitioned into the Consumer Products sector, working for the iconic Campbell Soup Company. Neely was part of the Financial Leadership Development program and her work included travel throughout a global business network supporting audits and providing advisory on re-engineering, controls, & accounting.  Later joining the core business as a Senior Financial Analyst focusing on product pricing, brand & financial management, product commercialization, & effectiveness of marketing spend. 

While maintaining a full-time schedule Neely completed her Executive MBA at Drexel University's LeBow College of Business. Shortly after graduation, Neely began a Financial Reporting & Consolidation role, building corporate scorecards, managing process improvement, & delivering strategic insights to the CFO & Senior Financial Leadership team.

Neely leaped into the Retail industry & championed the development of the Internal Audit function at URBN. Capitalizing on the entrepreneurial spirit of URBN, Neely took to technology business management leading a world-class Financial Transformation Program to overhaul the core financial systems and drove a portfolio of strategic initiatives in support of URBN's omni-channel brands including Urban Outfitters, Anthropologie, Free People, BHLDN, Terrain & Vetri.

Today, Neely brings her experiences to the Greater Philadelphia YMCA as CFO and is engaged in driving financial transformation while serving and building communities and connections to well being.

Today Rob is responsible for Microsoft's partnership with AT&T.

A Wisconsin native, Rob has a degree in Economics from Miami University, Oxford, OH. The joys of his life are his wife, two children and children-in-law, and three grandchildren. Whenever possible Rob enjoys snow skiing, fly-fishing, reading history, cooking, and pairing most of what he creates with the boldest red wines of Washington State.

headline: Managing Director of Public-Private Sector Technology Partnerships - Microsoft Corporation
about:
Forty years ago, before I had even gone to college, Bill Gates suggested I join his small startup and I have enjoyed an incredible career. For the first years I applied my skills to Microsoft’s internal IT systems and human resources structure but in the past 21 years I have found it especially exciting, applying those early business, technical and organizational learnings to a different set of problems.

I have a well-developed skill for understanding even the most complex technical and business concepts and translating them into strategies and tangible action plans that deliver results.  For twelve years I was Chief of Staff for Microsoft’s Chief Research and Strategy Officer. I was involved in advanced strategies resulting in new business startups, and incubations, such as Microsoft’s long term quantum computing effort which required the development and management of a complex business framework, international talent and facilities. I then worked for the Chief Research Officer who was leading innovative work in many areas, such as Artificial Intelligence, particularly in Cognitive Services (vision, speech, language, decision making) and Azure cloud applications.  Most recently, I have managed and developed worldwide strategic partnerships with academia, governments, and industry to grow Microsoft’s advanced high performance and quantum computing business opportunities.

In my roles, I have typically attended important meetings, even the most confidential, and acted as a “consigliore” with the well understood authority to act on executive’s behalf.  This was sometimes as simple as setting up a specific task team and following through on the associated deliverables, to driving things from strategy to execution.  Sometimes it involved complex opportunities with governments or partners aligned in achieving an important long term technical or business goal, such as establishing technology policy and regulatory frameworks or joint R&D programs. 

My skills in understanding complex technologies and translating thought into concrete actions are essential in a range of areas from providing support to a startup or to established companies with new technologies in accelerating the movement from strategy to action.

headline: CEO & Founder at Synapbox / Forbes 30 under 30 / MIT Innovators under 35
about:
I have been a technology innovator from the beginning of my professional career; from building algorithms to optimize digital models to re-imagining the way we build and interact in the real world.

As the Co-Founder and CEO of Synapbox I have been leading an innovative team that is reinventing the way we understand consumer behavior. By leveraging AI technology and visual computing to analyze facial expressions, attentional engagement and content attributes we are able to quantify the experience of the consumer with video and images. Synapbox achieves this at in real-time, at scale and on consumer personal devices without the use of any external hardware.

I envisage the work I am doing with Synapbox will not only make a huge impact in the media and advertising space, but will also allow this new layer of data to enhance human-computer interaction and potentially impact a variety of industries such as education, gaming, and health.

Please contact me if you want to learn more or be part of this new era of consumer understanding.

headline: Director and Global Head of Healthcare and Public Health at Google/YouTube
about:
A cardiologist, researcher and public health expert Garth Graham joins Google as Director and Global Head of Healthcare and Public Health at Google/YouTube and Google Health. He previously served in two US administrations as US Deputy Assistant Secretary for Minority Health and was Assistant Dean for Health Policy and Chief of Health Services Research in the department of medicine at the University of Florida School of Medicine, President of the Aetna Foundation as well as Vice President & Chief Community Health Officer at CVS Health. He currently serves on several boards, including the National Heart Lung, and Blood Institute Advisory Council; the Institute of Medicine Board on Population Health and the board of the National Quality Forum. 

An elected member of the National Academy of Medicine, Garth obtained his MD at Yale University School of Medicine, MPH at Yale School of Public Health, Internal Medicine at Massachusetts General Hospital and Cardiology fellowship at Johns Hopkins. He holds three board certifications including internal medicine, cardiology and interventional cardiology.

headline: CMO at Primasun | Healthcare & Innovation | New Product Development & Growth | Digital Transformation
about:
I leverage my diverse background and unique lens as a trained scientist (PhD in Chemistry), business strategist, and marketing leader to identify solutions that push the needle forward in healthcare and innovation. Currently, I serve as the Head of Marketing at Primasun, a digital healthcare start-up. As a member of the executive leadership team, I lead the planning, development and execution of Primasun’s marketing strategy to accelerate its growth. I am focused on building Primasun’s brand as a market leader in addressing sleep as a public health epidemic and closing the gap in sleep equity.

My career background includes a progressive blend of technical, marketing, and business leadership roles for a broad range of Fortune 500 healthcare organizations. I began my career as a bench chemist at Dupont, a multinational chemicals company, rapidly advancing to lead teams of chemists as well as quality control for laboratory operations. 

Following my tenure at Dupont, I moved into the healthcare space and joined GE Healthcare, working across different business verticals (service, commercial, and marketing) and modalities in global and US/Canada assignments. From there, I joined Siemens Healthineers, furthering my ability to deepen customer relationships, drive operational excellence, execute sales and marketing plans, and effectively provide solutions to advance care and improve outcomes. 

Deeply passionate about using creative storytelling to effectively attract and retain customers, gain internal traction, and build advocates, I thrive on taking complex challenges, creating strategies, building a framework, and breaking them into bite-sized chunks to identify solutions. I am proud to lend my voice, implement strategies that move the needle to solve some of the biggest challenges on our planet today (cost, quality, access, disparities in healthcare), and have an impact on society at large.

I’m interested in pursuing board leadership roles, and have completed the Women on Boards Program through Harvard Business School, the Johnson & Johnson Innovation Board Fellows Program, and the Women’s Executive Leadership: Business Strategies for Success at Wharton. I am a member of Women Execs on Boards and previously served as a Board Member for the DC Chapter of Girls Inc.

headline: Director of Development
about:
I believe healthcare is a human right and have focused my career on enabling quality health care access to all - regardless of gender, sexual orientation, race, religion, economic status, or citizenship. 

At Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), the world’s leading independent medical relief organization, I connect our vital movement to private sector partners in the United States. This includes corporations, foundations, philanthropists, and mass market donors. 

MSF-USA is entirely funded by private donors, and I lead the team that raises awareness and financial resources in support of MSF’s humanitarian operations in more than 70 countries.
